name: Alabama
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Alaska
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Arizona
law: Zoom is out of compliance with statute AZ REV ST § 15-1046.

name: Arkansas
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: California
law: Violates everything, namely CA BUS & PROF § 22584 & CA BUS & PROF § 22585, which states that K-12 website/application vendors can't use, share, disclose, or compile student information 'for any purpose other than educational purpose and improving their service; they can't sell the information and must delete the information if the school or district requests.'

name: Colorado
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Connecticut
law: The only related law is CT Gen St §10-234bb, which 'requires local/regional boards of education to enter into written contracts with a contractor any time such local or regional board of education shares or provides access to student information, student records, or student generated content with such contractor.'

name: Delaware
law: Delaware law requires vendors to 'delete data in reasonable time,' which Zoom makes no provisions for.

name: Florida
law: Like most states, Florida prohibits online services from selling, sharing, or renting a student's information.

name: Georgia
law: Prevents all commercial use of student data.

name: Hawaii
law: Hawaii has a 'delete data in reasonable time,' provision Zoom can't enforce.

name: Idaho
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Illinois
law: Prevents selling and renting student data.

name: Indiana
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Iowa
law: Prevents selling and renting student data.

name: Kansas
law: Prevents selling and renting student data and 'prohibits school districts from collecting biometric data and conducting survey on life-styles (sex history, religion, etc.) unless consent given in writing.'

name: Kentucky
law: If Zoom can reasonably be considered a 'cloud computing service,' defined as 'a service that provides, and that is marketed and designed to provide, an educational institution with account-based access to online computing resources,' Zoom can't use student data for anything other than maintaining its 'integrity' as a company, prohibiting use for advertising or commercial purposes.

name: Louisiana
law: 'Allows for transfer of student data to contracted vendors but also lists contract requirements: inclusion of privacy compliance standards, audits conducted under direction of local school superintendent, breach and notice procedure, and storage/deletion policy; places $10,000 fine on violation of the contract requirements.'

name: Maine
law: Requires service providers to clarify what student data they collect and how the data is maintained and used, provide notice before making any changes, prohibit retaining information, facilitate access and correction, get parental consent, and obtain consent for using data in a way 'inconsistent' with the privacy policy.

name: Maryland
law: Prohibits selling and disclosing data.

name: Massachusetts
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Michigan
law: Prohibits selling and renting

name: Minnesota
law: This bill 'places limits on the technology provider and disclosure or use of educational data, including prohibiting the sale, share, or dissemination of the data and use of data for any commercial purpose. Outside of specific exceptions schools and technology providers must not electronically access or monitor school issued device location, internet activity, keystrokes, camera or audio.'

name: Mississippi
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Missouri
law: Zoom can't sell student data or collect individual student data (criminal record, mental/health, biometric, etc.).

name: Montana
law: Prohibits selling data.

name: Nebraska
law: Prohibits selling or renting data.

name: Nevada
law: clarify what student data they collect and how the data is maintained and used, provide notice before making any changes, prohibit retaining information, facilitate access and correction.

name: New Hampshire
law: Prohibits selling and disclosing.

name: New Jersey
law: 'Prohibits online education services from disclosing student educational records, amassing profiles of student data for non-educational purposes, and requires deletion of data in certain instances.'

name: New Mexico
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: New York
law: Violates New York State Education Law § 2-d, which requires outside parties collect and disclose students' personally identifiable information only as necessary (banning selling and using for marketing) and only for educational purposes. There are many other provisions and compliance requirements Zoom can't feasibly enforce.

name: North Carolina
law: 'Prohibits collection of biometric and lifestyle information from students.'

name: North Dakota
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Ohio
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Oklahoma
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Oregon
law: Prohibits using data for commercial and 'secondary' purposes except for recommendation engines, personalized learning, and service improvement.

name: Pennsylvania
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Rhode Island
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: South Carolina
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: South Dakota
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Tennessee
law: Prohibits the collection of student data for commercial purposes.

name: Texas
law: Incredibly stringent state education requirements limiting student data collection here: https://capitol.texas.gov/tlodocs/88R/billtext/html/HB00018F.htm. Restricts the use of covered info, including but not limited to personally identifiable data, by an online application. See more details here

name: Utah
law: In Utah, students own their own personally identifiable data. This is incredibly interesting, but the implications are unclear.

name: Vermont
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Virginia
law: Zoom must provide each student's parent with access to a downloadable electronic copy of any student personal information pertaining to such student that has been collected, maintained, used, or shared. Also requires service providers to clarify what student data they collect and how the data is maintained and used, provide notice before making any changes, prohibit retaining information, facilitate access and correction, get parental consent, and obtain consent for using data in a way 'inconsistent' with the privacy policy.

name: Washington
law: Prohibits selling data or using it or any purpose agreed to without consent.

name: West Virginia
law: Must give parents opportunity to opt-out of sharing their student's data, and collection of lifestyle information is prohibited.

name: Wisconsin
law: No specific laws, subject to FERPA and PPRA.

name: Wyoming
law: The responsibility falls to the State Superintendent for protecting data privacy, but details are unclear.
